We also came across vibrant red crabs and even witnessed pearl hunting, adding more wonder to the journey. Another highlight was reaching the **mohana**, where the lake meets the sea. The vastness and serenity of the place were breathtaking. The beauty of this spot is something that simply cannot be described--it must be experienced.

What made this trip even more memorable was the rain. Cruising across the vast lake, with the gentle rain creating ripples in the water, felt like something out of a dream. The combination of nature's elements made it an extraordinary adventure, one that will remain forever in the depths of my memory.

Overall, the Chilka Lake boating experience was nothing short of spectacular, filled with unforgettable moments of awe and wonder. I'll cherish this trip for a lifetime.

name: Atul Lande
review_text:
**Chilika Lake**, located in Odisha, is the largest coastal lagoon in India and the second largest in the world. Spanning over 1,100 square kilometers, it stretches across the districts of Puri, Khurda, and Ganjam, offering a unique ecosystem that attracts nature lovers, bird watchers, and travelers.

One of Chilika Lakes most fascinating features is its **biodiversity**. It is home to over 160 species of birds, many of which are migratory and come from as far as Siberia and the Himalayas. The lake becomes a bird watcher's paradise, especially during the winter months, with species like flamingos, pelicans, and herons. The **Nalaban Bird Sanctuary**, located within the lake, is a key spot for observing these beautiful creatures.

Chilika is also home to the rare **Irrawaddy dolphins**, which can be spotted around Satapada, a small town near the lake. Dolphin watching tours are popular and offer an exciting experience for visitors.

The lakes **brackish water** ecosystem supports a rich variety of aquatic life, including prawns, crabs, and fish, making fishing a major livelihood for local communities. Chilika's waters are also famous for producing pearls, adding to its economic significance.

Boating on Chilika Lake is one of the highlights of visiting, with scenic rides available to islands like **Kalijai Island**, which has a famous temple, and **Honeymoon Island**, known for its serene beauty.

The best time to visit Chilika Lake is from **November to February**, when the weather is pleasant, and the migratory birds are at their peak. It is a perfect getaway for those seeking tranquility, wildlife, and a connection with nature.

review_text:
Very calm and beautiful. Spotting dolphins is quite tough but if you keep patience then you might be able to see a dolphin. You can also spot migratory birds but there is a particular season for that.
But before this, there are 2 major scams!! which can be avoided if you pay attention.
1) Chilika lake has 2 boating spots. One is controlled by the government called Satpada where boating rates are fixed and controlled by government. The other spot is owned by private players who charge extremely high prices for dolphin spotting. These people have partnered with majority of taxi drivers and therefore taxi drivers will take you to this private operated spot for their own commission. Even if you tell the taxi driver to take you to Satpada, he will still take you to this spot because of his own cut. Local people here will also claim this place as Satpada only but if you pressurize your driver then he might help you in negotiating the price or might take you to the actual place.
2) In the lake at some point, vendors will come to you showcasing red crabs and oysters with pearls. They will break the oyesters to show you pearls emerging from them. It is up to you whether to buy them or not.
About dolphin spotting :
Dolphins located here are blind. You have to be very attentive because they come only to the surface for breathing hence do not assume that you can spot dolphins jumping in the lake. They briefly come to the surface and then go back to the underwater. Since boats in the lake make a lot of noise, the operator will close the boat engines to maintain silence near the potential sightseeing area. Hence dolphins are usually sighted a little far from the boat. Spotting dolphins is 100% based on your luck.

name: Chandan Prakash Jha
review_text:
Chilika Lake in Odisha offers a captivating boating experience, showcasing the diverse beauty and wildlife that adorn its vast expanse. The journey begins with multiple points to embark on your adventure, allowing you to customize your exploration of this natural marvel. However, its essential to clarify the route and duration when booking your boat, as not all routes cover every highlighted destination, and costs may vary.

The boat ride takes you through a spectacular journey, offering glimpses of the Bird Sanctuary, Red Crab Point, Dolphin Point, Rajahansha, Island, Sea Mouth, Nalabana, Kalijai Temple, and the enchanting Mangrove Plantation. Its advisable to confirm the itinerary to ensure you dont miss out on any of these breathtaking locations.

While the boat services might seem a bit expensive, the views and experiences justify every penny spent. The scenery is nothing short of stunning, with birds gracefully soaring overhead, dolphins playfully leaping in designated areas, and the vibrant red crabs making a striking appearance at the Island and Sea Mouth.

A visit to the Island adds an extra layer of fascination to the journey. Here, locals share their knowledge about Pearl Gemstones, which are cultivated in the ocean beds within oysters. The process of extracting these gems, along with a display of various other stones and species, adds an educational and entertaining element to the trip. Bargaining skills come in handy when considering a purchase, allowing you to acquire these unique souvenirs at the most affordable rates.

In conclusion, exploring Chilika Lake is an absolute delight for nature enthusiasts and adventure seekers alike. The combination of breathtaking landscapes, diverse wildlife, and cultural encounters make it a truly memorable experience. While boat services may seem pricey, the priceless moments and memories forged during this journey make it well worth the investment. Chilika Lake stands as a testament to Odishas natural wonders, offering a perfect blend of tranquility and excitement for those who embark on its waters.

review_text:
Chilika Lake, located in Odisha, is a beautiful and unique lake that is home to a plethora of exotic and endangered species. It is the largest brackish water lake in India and one of the largest in Asia.

The lake is home to over 160 species of birds, including grey-headed fishing eagle, purple moorhen, Indian skimmer and black-bellied tern. It is also home to several species of fish, amphibians and reptiles, including the endangered Irrawaddy dolphins.

Visitors to the lake can enjoy a boat ride through the lake and get up close to the wildlife. From the boat, you can spot migratory birds, Irrawaddy dolphins and other aquatic animals. The lake also offers some stunning views of the surrounding landscape, and you can get a glimpse of the beautiful blue waters, which change colour depending on the season.

Apart from wildlife watching, visitors can also take part in activities like fishing, bird watching and angling. There are several resorts and lodges near the lake which offer comfortable accommodation and delicious local cuisine.

review_text:
Chilika Lake is a brackish water lake and a shallow lagoon with estuarine character spread across the districts of Puri, Khurda and Ganjam in the state of Odisha in eastern India. Fed by 52 rivers and rivulets, the waterspread area of Chilika varies between 900 to 1165 sq. km. during summers and monsoon respectively. The pear shaped lagoon is about 64.5 km. long and its width varies from 5 to 18 km. It is connected to the Bay of Bengal by a 32 km long and 1.5 km wide channel that mostly runs parallel to the Bay separated by a narrow spit whose width varies between 100 m to several kilometres.

The lagoon can be broadly divided into four ecological sectors based on salinity and depth, namely the southern zone, the central zone, the northern zone and the outer channel. A number of islands are present in the lagoon, prominent among which are Krushnaprasad, Nalaban, Kalijai, Somolo and Birds Islands.

A survey of the fauna at Chilika by the Zoological Survey of India in 1985-87 recorded over 800 species in and around the lagoon. The list includes a number of rare, threatened and endangered species including the Barakudia limbless skink.

Chilika Lake is a stunning lagoon located in the eastern coastal state of Odisha, India. It is the largest brackish water lagoon in Asia and is a designated Ramsar site, indicating its importance as a wetland ecosystem.

The lake is a haven for birdwatchers, with over 160 species of birds found in the area, including flamingos, pelicans, and herons. The lake also supports a rich marine life, with over 200 species of fish, crabs, and prawns found in its waters.

Visitors can take a boat ride around the lake to explore its various islands and witness the diverse flora and fauna of the region. The lake is surrounded by lush green hills, and the scenery is truly breathtaking.

One of the highlights of a visit to Chilika Lake is the opportunity to witness the traditional fishing practices of the local community. Visitors can witness fishermen using traditional nets and techniques to catch fish, crabs, and prawns.

The lake also has several small islands that are home to fishing communities and offer a glimpse into their unique way of life. Visitors can interact with the locals and learn about their customs and traditions.

Overall, Chilika Lake is a must-visit destination for anyone traveling to Odisha. It is a beautiful and serene location that offers a unique blend of natural beauty and cultural experiences. The lakes importance as a Ramsar site also highlights the need for conservation efforts to protect the delicate ecosystem and the livelihoods of the local communities.

A Birdwatchers Paradise: Chilika Lake
Chilika Lake, Indias largest brackish water lagoon, is a haven for nature enthusiasts, especially birdwatchers. Nestled between the Puri, Khurda, and Ganjam districts of Odisha, this pear-shaped lake offers a unique blend of natural beauty and biodiversity.
Key Attractions:
* Birdwatching: Chilika Lake is a wintering ground for migratory birds from Siberia, Mongolia, China, and other parts of Asia. Visitors can spot a variety of species, including flamingos, pelicans, geese, ducks, and herons. The best time to visit for birdwatching is between November and March.
* Irrawaddy Dolphins: These playful creatures can be seen swimming in the lake, especially in the northern part. Watching them interact with each other is a delightful experience.
* Kalijai Temple: Located on one of the islands in the lake, this temple is dedicated to Goddess Kalijai. It is a popular pilgrimage site and offers stunning views of the surrounding area.

Chilika Lake is a must-visit destination for anyone who loves nature and wildlife. Its serene beauty, rich biodiversity, and unique experiences make it a truly unforgettable place. Whether youre a seasoned birdwatcher or simply looking for a peaceful getaway.

name: Rhea Mishra
review_text:
I visited Chilika lake on a warm, cloudy afternoon with my family. We paid Rs. 3000 for 6 people for what was supposed to be a 2.5 hour long boat ride with two activities (seeing red crabs on an island and dolphin sighting). On our first stop for the red crab activity, we reached a little island that had 3 people. We saw the red crabs. Then came the fun part. One of the guys showed up with some clams and started extracting pearls from them left right and centre. We had no idea that clams generated pearls but the extraction process was so believable that we went with it anyway. We even tried our hands on the extraction process. The pearls felt plasticky to touch and a little too machine finished but we had no other reason to believe that he was faking it. He also managed to sell us two of the "pearls" for Rs. 150 each. This was after a lot of haggling. Previously he wanted Rs. 700 per Pearl. LOL.

He then proceeded to bring out some "reefs" from which he extracted emerald, ruby and Topaz. WHAT! We couldn't believe our eyes. But the extraction process looked EXTREMELY legit. Thankfully we didn't gullibly make any more purchases. Soon after this experience, we found out this entire gem stone extraction thing is a well known scam that has been running at Chilika Lake for years.

We proceeded to the next activity i.e. Dolphin sighting. It took us 1.5 hours to arrive at the location on the lake where the Dolphins are sighted usually. We saw absolutely no dolphins so that was a bust.

The reason why I gave the lake a 4 star is because the boat ride, albeit 1.5 hours longer than was promised to us (total 4 hours) was really relaxing and breezy. We lay down on the boat and took in serenity and the views. Was it worth 3k? Maybe. Would I do it again? No.

My piece of advice for people who are visiting the lake: please call out the Gem stone guy on his fake business. And if you have other activities planned for later in the day, strongly advise your boatman to not exceed the promised timelines.

name: Subhodip G.
review_text: Chilika Lake is a serene haven for nature enthusiasts. Its vast expanse of brackish water, dotted with islands, provides a picturesque setting. Boating through the tranquil waters offers a peaceful escape, while the surrounding villages showcase local life. The presence of the Nalabana Bird Sanctuary enhances the bird-watching experience. However, visitors should be mindful of conservation efforts to preserve this ecological treasure. Overall, Chilika Lake is a delightful destination that seamlessly blends natural beauty with wildlife encounters.

name: Umashankar Aditya
review_text:
Chilika Lake, situated in the state of Odisha, India, is Asias largest brackish water lagoon and a haven for biodiversity. Spanning over 1,100 square kilometers during the monsoon season, it is separated from the Bay of Bengal by a narrow sandy ridge. The lake is an ecosystem with a large fishery resource, supporting the livelihood of thousands of fishermen. It is renowned for its dynamic ecosystem, which hosts over 160 species of birds in the migratory season, including the rare and endangered Irrawaddy dolphins.

Declared a Ramsar site in 1981, Chilika Lake is a significant wetland of international importance, attracting eco-tourists and nature enthusiasts from across the globe. The lakes vast expanse is dotted with a number of islands, each with its own distinct flora and fauna. Nalabana Island, for example, is a birdwatchers paradise, turning into a breeding ground for birds during the winter months.

Chilikas unique biodiversity is not only a crucial habitat for wildlife but also a vital source for studying and conserving various species. The lakes scenic beauty, coupled with its rich marine and bird life, makes it a popular destination for boating, bird watching, and fishing, offering a serene escape into nature.

Efforts by the government and various NGOs to preserve the lakes ecosystem have seen significant success, including the revival of the population of Irrawaddy dolphins and an increase in the arrival of migratory birds. Chilika Lake remains a symbol of natural beauty and ecological diversity, emphasizing the importance of conservation and sustainable use of natural resources.

review_text:
When you visit Puri, lake Chilika automatically comes to your itinerary.
A lagoon in nature, its not at all deep. Weve even seen buffaloes crossing it. But near its mouth to the Bay of Bengal, its deep indeed.
You hire a cab from Puri and fix your destination. Google map will guide you better than me. But the points I would like to share is purely of travel benefit.
I visited the place twice and on either occasion, it was late January. During this season its the best as you can see thousands of migratory birds. The lake or lagoon, whatever you say, is low lands and this can be appreciated before you reach. The lowlands, some still have water resembling scaattered ponds with full of aviary guests from Siberia.
The lagoon has many entry points. Most have boat halts wherefrom you can hire your boats. Rates are reasonable. 4 to 6 persons can be accommodated in one. Youve restaurants as well where you can preorder your food. Dont forget to include jumbo prawns in your menu, btw.
The boat ride is pleasant, lazy and refreshing. As your boat moves towards the mouth, the chances of dolphin visibility becomes more. But you should maintain silence, otherwise the dolphins may go far to the sea and you kiss the dust.
The ride is about half an hour to 45 mins after which youll be left to your restaurant.

I have start my journey from PURI Railways Station. Chilika Lake is asias largest brackish water lagoon with water spread ranging from 1165 sq km m the rainy season to 906 sq km in the dry season is nestled in the heart of the coastal Odisha (Orissa). It extends from Bhusandpur in Puri district in the North to Rambha-Malud in Ganjan district in the South, separated from the Bay of Bengal by a 60 km long narrow strip of marshy islands and sand-flats.
Some of the prominent islands like Nalabana, Kalijal, Somolo, Honeymoon, Break-fast, Birds and Rajahansa inhabited by small subsistence fishermen families, are popular destinations for daily boat trips. Because of its rich bio-diversity and socio-economic importance, Chilika was designated as a Ramsar site in 1981 to afford better protection.

name: KULDDEP Patel
review_text:
it was awesome place...Chilika Lake is a brackish water lagoon, spread over the Puri, Khurda and Ganjamdistricts of Odisha state on the east coast of India, at the mouth of the Daya River, flowing into the Bay of Bengal, covering an area of over 1,100 km2. It is the largest coastal lagoon in India and the second largest coastal lagoon in the world[4][5][dubious - discuss] after The New Caledonian barrier reef in New Caledonia.[6]

It is the largest wintering ground for migratory birds on the Indian sub-continent. The lake is home to a number of threatened species of plants and animals.[7][8]

The lake is an ecosystem with large fishery resources. It sustains more than 150,000 fisher-folk living in 132 villages on the shore and islands.[9][10]

The lagoon hosts over 160 species of birds in the peak migratory season. Birds from as far as the Caspian Sea, Lake Baikal, Aral Sea and other remote parts of Russia, Kirghiz steppes of Mongolia, Central and southeast Asia, Ladakh and Himalayas come here. These birds travel great distances; migratory birds probably follow much longer routes than the straight lines, possibly up to 12,000 km, to reach Chilika Lake.

In 1981, Chilika Lake was designated the first Indian wetland of international importanceunder the Ramsar Convention.[11][12]

According to a survey, 45 percent of the birds are terrestrial in nature, 32 percent are waterfowl, and 23 percent are waders. The lagoon is also home to 14 types of raptors. Around 152 rare and endangered Irrawaddy dolphins have also been reported. Plus, the lagoon supports about 37 species of reptiles and amphibians.[13]

The highly productive Chilika Lagoon eco-system with its rich fishery resources sustains the livelihood for many fishermen who live in and near the lagoon. The water spread area of the lagoon ranges between 1165 and 906 km2during the monsoon and summer respectively. A 32 km long, narrow, outer channel connects the lagoon to the Bay of Bengal, near the village Motto. More recently a new mouth has been opened by CDA which has brought a new lease of life to the lagoon.

Microalgae, marine seaweeds, sea grasses, fish and crab also flourish in the brackish water of the Chilika Lagoon. Especially the recovery of sea grass beds in recent years is a welcoming trend which may eventually result in re-colonizations of endangered dugongs.

name: Pranav Kodial
review_text:
Short version: Good for a serene early morning boat ride to watch dolphins and birdwatching in season. BEWARE the red crab-spotting and pearl-semiprecious stone SCAM!

Long version:
Its a large lake, good for a serene boat ride. We caught a glimpse of a dolphin, some kingfishers and other birds. But we had gone late morning; an early morning trip would probably be better for birdwatching and dolphin sighting.

The dolphin sighting-red crab spotting boat ride is a total scam. 5250 for a five-person boat ride (actual ride lasting only about 1 to 1.5 hours). The booking office didnt have any official rate signboard. When asked about it the guy just shrugged and avoided the question. Also, we were told each boat carried only five passengers so we were forced to book two boats for our nine family members. During the ride, we saw several other boats taking 10 passengers.

The boat ride package included a visit to a beach to spot some special large red crabs. The boat stopped at one lake bank. A guy got in with a medium sized kitchen utensil and showed us some regular small grey crabs. He gave us some yarns about the crabs bodies and their eyes glowing bright red to signal an impending cyclone. A quick n quiet internet search revealed it was all nonsense.

It also struck us as odd that fishermen worldwide used their legendary skills by observing the sea, skies, winds and air moisture (and of course, official weather alerts) to anticipate cyclones whereas here, the fishermen go searching for fluorescent red crabs with satanic eyes.

The same guy then proceeded to show us oysters (actually, just regular clams), some diagrams and an explanation how pearls are formed etc. Then he broke open some clams one by one, expressing great regret at not finding a pearl inside. Then he chose one (probably with some identification mark) broke it open and gave a nice gasp of delight. He gently extracted a PEARL and excitedly told us how one in a thousand oysters yields such beautiful pearls (wow, we were so blessed!). He even placed it on a wooden plank and banged it with another plank to prove it was genuine and wouldnt break.

Then he went on to show us more semiprecious stones by breaking barnacles, luckily finding a rainbow crystal stones and a coral after breaking a few. He re-emphasized how fortunate we were and we could buy them for 650 per stone/ pearl whereas the same would cost us at least 5000 in shops.

What he didnt know was that some of us were expert in recognising real pearls and semiprecious stones from plastic beads.

I would have given Mr. Gemologist an Oscar Award for his acting but I didnt have one in my pocket at the time.

Needless to say, we played along and oohed and aahed all through his performance, but finally told him we were not interested. He grew irritated and persistently asked us why we werent buying them. We told him we had come to just sightsee and not buy anything. Visibly angry at our wasting his time (and some clams and barnacles), he suddenly got up and shouted at our boatman to take us away in Oriya language (perhaps including some native swear words at us ).

Then the boatman stopped at a beach with some huts selling coconut water--probably with some more scamsters waiting for us. By then we were bored with all this bullshi*t and ordered our boatman to take us back.

We realised that the whole boat ride was an elaborate scam, beginning right from the booking office guys, the boatman, the fake gem sellers and God knows who else. Worse, all this was going on under the very nose of the concerned Tourism department office. On searching the internet, several visitors mentioned similar experiences.

We had a good laugh about our experience but also felt saddened that many tourists especially foreigners were getting conned.

name: Arnab Sarkar
review_text:
Rambha Chilka campaign

Chilka is the largest natural lake (lagoon) in Asia. The extent of this Chilkar touches the districts of Puri, Ganjam, Khurda. Chilka has three main gateways.

1) Satpara of Puri (famous for dolphins)
2) Barakula of Balugaon
3) Rambha of Balugaon

Rambha is located between Balugaon and Brahmpur stations. 35 km from Balugaon station are Rambha Jetty Ghat and Panthanivas. Rambhat can be reached from Balugaon station 35 km away by auto for 400/500 taka.

Stay at Odisha OTDC Panthanivas. A very beautiful residence in the garden next to Rambha jetty. The beauty of Chilka can be enjoyed from the room of the house. Morning tea breakfast is free. OTDC website for online booking and Utkal Bhawan office in Lenin Sarni, Kolkata for offline booking. Ten percent discount is available for senior citizens, physically challenged. Check in/out time is 12 noon. Food at Rambha Panthanivas is very good.

Then travel to Chilka. There are various islands in Rambhat Chilka.

1) Breakfast Island (3 km),
2) Ghantasheela Hill Island (2 km),
3) Birds (Dinosaurs Park) Island (5 km),
4) Honeymoon Island (8 km),
5) Sanacuda Island (7 km)

These islands can be visited within three hours by renting five seater (speed boat) or ten seater (motor boat) from Rambha Panthnibus in different packages. Rambha Panth Niwas has three types of boating packages. The cost for five islands is 2730 taka, the cost of going to the first three islands is 1700 taka and the cost of visiting the first two islands is 1000 taka. There are also many private boats at the jetty.

Rambha trip can be taken by adding one day extra to Puri, Gopalpur, Daringbadi trip. One of the 51 Peeths can be visited from Rambha to Taratarini Temple, Gopalpur or Barakul via Tampara Lake.

Rambha can be reached by alighting at Balugaon station on all trains going south to Chennai.
